displaytitle: Human figure with tattooed whale fluke tails on cheeks
creditline: The Lloyd E. Cotsen, Class of 1950, Eskimo Bone and Ivory Carving Collection

titles.title: Human figure with tattooed whale fluke tails on cheeks

texts.textentryhtml:
Ancient ivories tattooed with whale flukes on the cheeks are rare. In the historic period, the daughters of famous Yupik whalers wore similar tattoos to advertise their fathers’ hunting prowess. Although the spurred lines radiating across the
torso may represent an elaborately styled outer garment, it is more likely that they signify charm straps and waistbands that continue toward the dorsal surfaces. Other corporeal markings perhaps indicate tattoos, especially those linear arrangements placed on the breasts.

Okvik Figures


Prized by European and Anglo American collectors and artists for their elegant abstraction, Okvik figural sculptures remain enigmatic in terms of their original use. They may once have served as effigies of ancestors, as children’s playthings, or as implements for shamanic ritual—they also may have served all of these functions. As epitomized by these examples, such figures typically are composed of a simple rectilinear body, with most sculptural attention focused on the head. Fine incisions sometimes seem to refer to clothing or underlying skeletal structures; in other cases, incisions parallel tattoo patterns known from historic times.
texts.remarks: 2015 AAA Reinstallation - "WC1 Arctic Alaska". Group chat of three objects: 1998-499, 1997-106, and 1997-129
